text: as the bombs were falling outside Samia
was brought to the silicon hospital she
was struggling to breathe and her skin
was burning along with dozens of others
the two-year-old was given oxygen she
could hardly see but it wasn't just fear
in her eyes the doctor said she'd been
poisoned in a chlorine gas attack today
she's back at home a little quiet but
much recovered Kathy a new kitten is
getting her and her sister's attention
samia's grandfather was with her during
the attack he says the world has turned
its back on Syria when a two-day baby
girl inhales chlorine gas or when a
two-and-a-half year old is suffocating
and saliva is coming out of her mouth
and she's dying in front of me and I'm
not able to do anything for her I didn't
hear anyone from the international
community condemned this all they said
was allegedly used chlorine gas come on
the bombs landed here just 15 meters
from their home they came said
eyewitnesses from government helicopters
in this rebel-held neighborhood were
trying to remove any contamination from
the shells
they've taken samples the UN has opened
an investigation into the suspected
attack despite plenty of evidence to the
contrary Syria denies using chemical
weapons Samia is getting better but she
still needs oxygen more importantly
she's back at home and despite the
attack her family say they and their
neighbors won't abandon eastern Aleppo
Quentin Somerville BBC news Barrett
